content.webTitle: Italy manager Cesare Prandelli tenders resignation as nation rages over exit

fields.headline: Italy manager Cesare Prandelli tenders resignation as nation rages over exit
fields.bodyText: Anger, indignation and a grudging acknowledgement that Cesare Prandelli’s team had fallen woefully short of expectations mingled in the sour cocktail Italians were forced to ingest after their side’s elimination from Brazil 2014. The team’s failure led to the immediate and “irrevocable” resignations of both the manager and the president of the Italian federation, Giancarlo Abete. Prandelli said: “When a professional project fails, it is right to take the responsibility.” Neither offer has so far been taken up. He said he and the FIGC’s chief had for four years “camouflaged well the problems of Italian football” and he complained about allegations of financial impropriety that had been levelled at them. But Prandelli added: “If I make a professional mistake, that is a different matter and I assume all responsibility.” Corriere dello Sport reminded readers that it was the first time in 48 years that Italy had failed in successive World Cups to get beyond the initial round. Within minutes of the final whistle, Prandelli told a TV interviewer: “The sending off of Marchisio left a mark on the game and our World Cup. It is absurd to be left with 10 players in a match like this. There weren’t such bad fouls – you can’t condition a game as important as this in that way.” But when asked about a possible resignation, he replied: “We’ll see now.” Reactions on social media ranged from the furious to the witty by way of the fatalistically cynical. “Unbelievable! Ball boy turns referee [and] expels Italy from World Cup” raged @FrankMo_. For @BeppeBergonzi, tweeting in English, “The ‘Biter’ team won”. Earlier when the Mexican referee, Marco Antonio Rodríguez Moreno, showed Marchisio a red card, @nicoperdire had posted a tweet that said: “Referee’s wife confirms: he’s a cuckold.” Italian fans had feared the worst when they learned of the official’s surname. Another Moreno – Byron Moreno – was bitterly accused of tipping the scales against Italy in the national side’s encounter with South Korea during the 2002 World Cup. Nor did it inspire confidence that the Mexican who oversaw night’s decider had the nickname in his own country of “little Dracula” – an allusion to his resemblance to a character in a popular TV show. To top it all when not handing out red cards to Italians he is a Protestant pastor. But if @gennaromontana was angry it was at the performance of a lacklustre Italian side. “What a disgrace,” he tweeted. “There are no excuses. Full stop.” @Sweetkisskaty thought “We only played with spirit at the end.” Others were inclined to be more charitable. @maurizioft asked: “If Costa Rica and Uruguay get through and Italy and England go home, there has to be a reason. No?” By way of explanation he attached a hashtag that referred to the Brazilian climate. Such considerations cut little ice with professional reporters, however. Maurizio Crosetti writing for the website of the Italian daily, La Repubblica, said: “The sending off of Marchisio after an hour was excessive. That foul was worth at most a warning. But before and after (and in the ‘before’ let’s include the game against Costa Rica) Prandelli’s side didn’t put together a thing.” Il Giornale, the family newspaper of Silvio Berlusconi, Italy’s former prime minister and the owner of Milan, struck a similar note. “There were a few mistakes on the part of the referee – the excessively severe removal of Marchisio and [his failure to send off] Suárez. But the Azzurri did almost nothing. And they have reaped what they sowed,” wrote Piero Minotti.
